intro: Dalechampia papillistigma, commonly known as the hairy bladderpod, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its distinctive, inflated, bladder-like fruits that are covered in fine, hairy structures. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils along stream banks and in wetlands. Its leaves are alternate, ovate to lanceolate, and often have a rough texture. Dalechampia papillistigma is part of the Euphorbiaceae family, which includes many plants with milky sap and unique floral structures.
